Problem:
Consider a complex function \(z(t) = x(t) + iy(t)\), where \(x(t)\) and \(y(t)\) evolve over time governed by a system of coupled linear differential equations. The system is represented by \(\dot{z} = Mz\), where \(M\) is a constant matrix. We examine the influence of the Laplace transformation \( \mathcal{L}(z)(s) = \int_0^\infty e^{-st}z(t) dt \) on causal inference between \(x(t)\) and \(y(t)\).

If an intervention is applied at time \(t_1\) where a new function \(h(z) = Qz\) (Q is a constant matrix) changes the trajectory, will the state \( z(T) \) at \(T > t_1\) depend solely on \(M\) and not on the intervening transformation?
Explanation: The intervention with \(h(z) = Qz\) introduces a new matrix dynamical influence over the system, effectively altering the trajectory of \(z(t)\) starting from \(t_1\) onwards. The final state \(z(T)\) thus depends on the interplay between \(M\) and \(Q\), and not just on \(M\).
